Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Since CO2 stayed more or less constant over this time scale, so did temperature.
CO2: The increase in buried carbon raises one of atmospheric carbon's sinks.  Carbon sources (which remain constant in this scenario) are now lower than carbon removal, causing an decrease  It will take longer than 200 years to cause a level change though.
Volcano: Volcanoes, mountain level, and weathering of buried carbon stay the same throughout this scenario.
Ice: Because temperature remained nearly constant, ice levels did to.
Sea: Because temperature (and ice level) remained fairly constant, so did sea level, weathering, and carbonate deposition.
Sediment: This scenario assumes carbon burial by sediments increses  It starts at a moderately low level (2).  It increases to level 3 to start the process.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 dropped, so did temperature.
CO2: Because C sources (constant) is lower than C sinks, atmospheric carbon decreased.
Ice: Temperature drop causes polar ice accumulation, raising the planet's ice level.
Sea: Because temperature dropped and ice level,  sea level dropped.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature dropped, the planet experiences less rain, decreasing the weathering rate.
CO3 Desposition: Lower weathering rate washes less Ca and C to sea, decreasing carbonate deposition rate, decreasing the C sinks, although not enough to move system back to equilibrium.
Sediment: By 100,000 years, carbon burial has increased from its initial level of 2 to 4.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 dropped, so did temperature.
CO2: Because C sources (constant) is lower than C sinks, atmospheric carbon decreased.
Ice: Temperature drop causes polar ice accumulation, raising the planet's ice level.  The planet is now in a snowball earth state.
Sea: Because temperature dropped and ice level,  sea level dropped to a minimum.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature dropped, the planet experiences less rain, decreasing the weathering rate.
CO3 Desposition: Lower weathering rate washes less Ca and C to sea, decreasing carbonate deposition rate, decreasing the C sinks, although not enough to move system back to equilibrium.
